title: 111_hr2151
content:
The Fair Pay Act of 2009, also known as the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, includes findings related to fair pay. Congress finds wage rate differentials based on sex, race, and national origin depress wages, hinder labor utilization, cause disputes, burden commerce, and constitute unfair competition. Discrimination in hiring and promotion is also noted. Discrimination in hiring and promotion has maintained a segregated workforce, with women and people of color often working in occupations dominated by individuals of their same sex, race, and national origin. Data from the United States Census Bureau in 2007 showed that women working full-time earned roughly 78 cents for every dollar earned by men. Despite accounting for key factors influencing earnings, a 20 percent pay gap remains unexplained, partially attributed to women earning less. Discrimination in compensation based on sex, race, and national origin persists despite laws prohibiting such practices. Eliminating these barriers would help address wage differentials and benefit the economy. The curr_chunk discusses the benefits of reducing wage differentials created by discrimination, such as decreasing the number of low-wage earners among women and people of color and promoting stable families by enabling fair pay for working family members. SEC. 3. EQUAL PAY FOR EQUIVALENT JOBS. Amendment to Section 6 (29 U.S.C. 206) prohibits wage discrimination based on sex, race, or national origin within the same establishment for equivalent jobs, except for instances allowed by seniority or merit systems. The text chunk outlines exceptions to wage discrimination based on sex, race, or national origin, including seniority, merit, production-based earnings, and factors like education or experience. The employer must show that these factors are job-related or serve a legitimate business purpose. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission shall issue guidelines outlining exceptions to wage discrimination based on sex, race, or national origin, including factors like seniority, merit, production-based earnings, education, or experience. The employer must demonstrate that these factors are job-related or serve a legitimate business purpose. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will issue guidelines for determining if a job is dominated by a specific sex, race, or national origin. Employers cannot reduce an employee's wage rate to comply with wage discrimination laws. Labor organizations cannot cause employers to discriminate against employees. Any withheld wages in violation of wage discrimination laws are considered unpaid minimum amounts owed to the employee. In violation of paragraph (1)(A), unpaid minimum wages or overtime compensation are deemed under this section. The term 'labor organization' refers to any organization dealing with employers on grievances, disputes, wages, and working conditions. 'Equivalent jobs' are those with similar requirements. Section 13(a) is amended to include sections 6(d) and (h). SEC. 4. PROHIBITED ACTS. Section 15(a) (29 U.S.C. 215(a)) is amended to include protections against discrimination for individuals who oppose unlawful acts, make charges, testify, assist, or participate in investigations related to section 6(h). It also prohibits discrimination against employees who inquire about, disclose, compare, or discuss wages, or who support others in doing so. The employee exercised, enjoyed, aided, or encouraged any right protected by section 6(h). SEC. 5. REMEDIES. (a) Enhanced Penalties.--Section 16(b) (29 U.S.C. 216(b)) is amended to hold employers liable for compensatory or punitive damages for violating specific sections of the law, with exceptions for punitive damages against the United States. Additionally, the amendment clarifies the scope of employee actions and court jurisdiction in enforcing these penalties. Section 16(c) (29 U.S.C. 216(c)) is amended to allow for additional compensatory or punitive damages in cases of violations of subsections (d) or (h) of section 6. The amendment clarifies the types of damages that can be sought in such cases. In cases of violations of subsections (d) or (h) of section 6, additional compensatory or punitive damages can be sought. Expert fees can also be awarded as part of the costs in actions brought for a violation of section 6(h). Class actions can be maintained as provided by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. SEC. 6. RECORDS. Every employer subject to section 6(h) must preserve records documenting wage rate calculations and report to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission as required by regulations. Every employer subject to section 6(h) must submit a report to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission disclosing wage rates paid to employees based on classification, position, or job title, as well as information on sex, race, and national origin. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission requires employers to submit reports disclosing wage rates by classification, position, or job title, including employee information on sex, race, and national origin. Confidentiality of employees must be protected in these reports, with regulations in place to ensure no individual names are included. The Commission may publish relevant information and data as needed. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission collects data from employers on wage rates by classification, position, and employee demographics. They use this information for statistical purposes and may publish studies based on it. Regulations allow for inspection and copying of reports submitted to the Commission. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission collects data from employers on wage rates and demographics for statistical purposes. They issue rules for reporting requirements to prevent evasion and may simplify reports for certain employers. SEC. 7. RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM; REPORT TO CONGRESS. Section 4(d) (29 U.S.C. 204(d)) is amended to require the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to conduct studies and provide information on implementing provisions prohibiting wage rate discrimination based on sex, race, or national origin. This includes research, education, and technical assistance to address and eliminate such discrimination. The Secretary is tasked with correcting wage rate differentials, publishing findings for compliance, sponsoring educational programs, and providing technical assistance. The biennial report to Congress includes an evaluation and appraisal. The Secretary's biennial report to Congress must include a separate evaluation and appraisal of the implementation of section 6(h). SEC. 8. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. (a) Congressional Employees. Section 203(a)(1) of the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended to include subsections (a)(1), (d), and (h) of section 6. Section 203(b) is also amended to allow remedies under section 16(f) of the Act. 
(b) Executive Branch Employees. Section 413(a)(1) of title 3, United States Code, is amended as per the Presidential and Executive Office Accountability Act. The Executive Office Accountability Act (Public Law 104-331; 110 Stat. 4053) is amended to include subsections (a)(1), (d), and (h) of section 6. Remedies under section 16(f) of the Act are also allowed in appropriate cases. The amendments made by this Act will be effective one year after its enactment.
